richcontent.text: Electric Charge comes in two types, which we call (+) and (-)
\latex Unlike charges attract, and like charges repel according to Coulomb's Law, which says:\\ \qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad \bold {\vec F = k\frac{$|q_1|$|q_2|}{r^2}}
Electric Charge is \underline{conserved}. The net charge of an isloated system canno change.
Conserved in the universe
Energy
Linear Momentum(\vec p = m\vec v)
Angular momentum (spin = \vec L = I\vec\omega)
Charge - main concept in Electric Filed
The charge \bold e is the fundamental unit of charge. you never find a free particle in nature with charge = fraction of e.
Coulomb's Law state that the magnitude \bold F of the force between two charges separated by distance r is given by \\ \qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad {\vec F = k\frac{$|q_1|$|q_2|}{r^2}}
k = constant = 9.0\cdot10^9 \frac{N \cdot m^2}{C^2}
We need to use the unit vectors since Coulomb's Law only gives us how strong the force is.
Point Charge (0D)
Q
Line Charge (1D)
\lambda = \frac{Q}{L} [\frac{C}{m}]
Surface Charge(2D)
\sigma = \frac{Q}{A} [\frac{C}{m^2}]
Volume Charge(3D)
\rho = \frac{Q}{V} [\frac{C}{m^3}]
Defintion

Surrounding every charge (or group of charges) is a thing, called \textit {electric filed} \, \vec E (it is a vector thing) \\ \qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\vec E = \frac{\vec F_{on q}}{q} = \frac{kQ}{r^2}\hat r [\frac{N}{C}]
Positive Charge \rightarrow Filed Point \bold {away}
Negative Charge \rightarrow Filed Point \bold {toward}
\latex Superpostion Pronciple: \bold {E_{total}} = $E_1 $+ $E_2 + ...
Gauss's Law is one of the four funamental laws of electricity and magnetism called \bold {Maxwell's Equation}
Before diving to Gauss's Law we need to understand a new concept called the electric flux \phi through a surface.
we consider an imaginary surface which cuts across some E-filed lines. We say that there is some electric flux though this surface.
but we must understand something called \textit {Surface vector}.

A surface vector it's an area with direction, \vec A = A\hat n. \\ Magnitude of vector \vec A = area a of a surface \\ Direction of vector \vec A = directon prpendicular(normal) to a surface whihc is the direction of the unit normal \hat n
We have an ambiguity in the direction \hat n. Every flat surface has two perpendicular directions.
So the electric flux \phi through a surface A defined as \\ \qquad\qquad\quad \phi = \vec E \cdot \vec A = EAcos(\theta).
The flux \bold {\phi} has the following geometrical interpretation\\ \bold{|flux|}\propto the \bold{numbers} of \bold{electric} \bold{filed} lines crossing the surface.

node.TEXT: Think of the E-filed as rain flowing through an open window of area A.
The flux is a measure of the amount of rain flowing through the window

richcontent.text: To get a big flux, you need a large E, a large A, and you need the area perpendicular to the E-filed vector
Which means the area vector \vec A is \underline {parallel} to \vec E.

node.TEXT: But this formula only works if the surface is flat and the E-filed is constant.

richcontent.text: if the E-filed varies with position and/or the surface is not flat, we need more general definition of flux, we need to integrate how fun is that
\bold{\phi} = \int\vec E\cdot d\vec a = "surface integral of \bold {E}"
\oint \vec E \cdot d\vec a = \frac{q_{enclosed}}{\epsilon_0}
In words, the electric flux through any \underline{closed} surface S is a constant (\frac{1}{\epsilon_0}) times the total charge inside S.
A surface is closed if it has no edges, like a sphere. For a closed surface, the direction of d\bold a is alwyas the \underline{outward} normal.
The constant \bold {epsilon\,nought} is related to k by k = \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}
\bold {\epsilon_0} = 8.85\cdot10^{-12}
When the Filed lines \bold{exit} a closed surface, the flux there is \bold{positive}.When the Field lines \bold{enter} a closed surface, the flux is \bold {negative}.
\bold{Note}: If a closed surface S encloses no charges, then the number of lines entering must equal the number of lines existing.
So only charges inside the surface can contribute to the flux through the surface. Positive charges inside produce positive flux; negative charges produce negative flux.
Gauss's Law is \bold{always\,true} (it's a LAW). but it is not always useful.
Only in situations with very high symmetry it is easy to compute the flux integral \oint\vec E\cdot d\vec a.
In these few cases of high symmetry, we can use Gauss's Law to compute the E-filed

node.TEXT: Using Gauss's Law to solve for the E-Filed

richcontent.text: Spherical Symmetry \rightarrow \bold {Sphere}(Point Charge) we use\rightarrow\vec E=\frac{kQ}{r^2}
Cylindrical Symmetry\rightarrow\bold{Cylinder}(Line Charge)\rightarrow\vec E=\frac{\lambda}{2\pi r\epsilon_0}
Planar Symmetry \rightarrow \bold {Pillbox} (Sheet Charge)\rightarrow\vec E =\frac{\sigma}{2\epsilon_0}
Inside a Conductor \rightarrow \vec E = 0
Charge moves to the surface
